In this article, we investigate the effect of synthetic solvents on the surface characteristics of the zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) and its photocatalytic activities.Different solvents (deionized (DI) water -ZIF-8 (W), methanol -ZIF-8(M), and a combination of ammonia and ethanol -ZIF-8(A)) were employed to prepare three ZIF-8 samples at room temperature.The fourth sample was obtained after 24 h immersion of ZIF-8(A) in methanol to evacuate pores which we named ZIF-8(AM).These four samples were

that for applications in photocatalysis, not only the magnitude of the bandgap but also the absolute positions of the band edges are important. To assess the capability of as-prepared photocatalysts in the reduction of CO 2 , the yield of methanol production using each sample was measured and compared as shown in Fig. 7. using ICON atomic force microscope (BRUKER, USA).Also, a 125 W mercury vapor lamp (OSRAM, Germany) was used as the excitation source for the study of photocatalysts wavelength in the range between 300 and 700 nm. In this article, we investigate the effect of synthetic solvents on the surface characteristics of the zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) and its photocatalytic activities.Different solvents (deionized (DI) water -ZIF-8 (W), methanol -ZIF-8(M), and a combination of ammonia and ethanol -ZIF-8(A)) were employed to prepare three ZIF-8 samples at room temperature.The fourth sample was obtained after 24 h immersion of ZIF-8(A) in methanol to evacuate pores which we named ZIF-8(AM).These four samples were

with different types of ZIF-8 synthesized using various solvents.Although the reported reaction conditions are not similar, it can suitably prove the role of surface heterogeneity in the methanol production yield. In order to evaluate the stability and cyclic usability of samples, XRD, FTIR, UV-vis, and GC analyses were performed for recovered ZIF-8 photocatalysts (after 1 h of reaction) and compared with fresh samples as shown in Fig. S2 to S4, and Fig. 8 18,22,52,53.We have recently discussed in our

have recently discussed in our previous work 22 that the ZIF-8 structure unveils structural instability in long-term exposure (at least 2 h) to water and in the presence of CO 2 due to carbonic acid production.Nonetheless, in our system, the required reaction time is only 1 h (60 min) which won't cause any stability issues for the samples.As can be seen in Fig. S2 to Fig. S4, the XRD, FTIR, and UV-vis analyses of recovered photocatalysts are similar to the fresh samples confirming the high stability of
